Many years ago, a bright young college student (yours truely) wrote a philosophical paper entitled "Morals as a Biological Imperative." I won't force the good people on this forum to wade through the entire 40 pages, but the main idea has served me well for all these years when I have been tasked to answer the question from my religious friends: "Without God, where do your morals come from?"
 
 In light of the current political and social situation in America and the world today, this seems like a good time to explore this question once again.
 
 Accepting all the evidence at face value, and concluding that man has indeed evolved from more primitive life forms, it seems logical, even obvious, that what we refer to as "morality" is simply our expression of certain biological imperatives that have evolved along with us.
 
 To avoid all the subtlties and permutations delt with in the longer paper, let's boil down this illustration to "good vs. evil."
 
 All succseful mutations leading to advancement along the evolutionary path incorporate certain "biological imperatives" required for the species to survive and prosper. These include things like the drive to procreate, fight or flight, the ability to evaluate energy expenditure vs. energy intake (choosing our food), etc. These things are common to almost all life.
 
 As a species, man has evolved into a social animal. All of our success is a result of this evolved condition. We have become the dominant life form on our planet because our social nature allows us to do things that would be impossible for individuals. The survival and continued evolutionary progress of our species depends upon this social structure.
 
 When some condition or action threatens this social structure, we instictively know that it is wrong. Being humans, and having evolved the ability to reason and think about such things, we have identified these things and labeled them. We call them "evil." Murder, war, theft, disorder, etc. are all examples of things that threaten our social structure. We do not need to be told that these things are wrong; we know it because we have evolved to know it. Our biological imperatives react negatively to these things.
 
 Conversely, those actions and conditions that tend to support society, to make it safer and more comfortable, are identified as "good." As a society, and as individuals, we tend to promote, support, and practice those things that we instinctivly know are "good." Those things that allow us to continue to evolve and thrive.
 
 I won't get into the discussion of religion and how it tends to work against the "good" and attract "evil." That is for another time; but for those who still feel that God is required to tell them what is "good" or "evil," I'll let you attempt to answer this question:
 
 Long before the advent of any modern religion, those things we call good and evil had been identified and labeled as such; even codified in writing. Mankind has known for a long, long time, that murder, theft, disease, etc. are "evil" and has worked against them. Why?

 It's possible to argue that the evolution of morality can be explained as the expression of self-interest. To put the point very crudely, individuals require the co-operation of others in the basic struggle to survive. By refraining from harming other human beings, I help myself in this struggle. On a beach on the island of Floreana is a barrel which for more than a century has served as a mailbox. Originally a gentle conspiracy of sailors to exchange mail, it is now used by tourists. Everyone who visits Floreana leaves an unstamped post card or letter in the barrel, and takes any mail addressed to anyone close to home.
 
 God is not present and does not require this behavior. Floreana itself has a frightening legacy. For much of this century, it was inhabited by a handful of human beings, several of whom came to mysterious, suspicious ends. Others left the island; the sole survivor of those times still on the island is a woman who (until she became too old) was visited by many of the tours; her colorfulness rested on the fact that she could tell about murders, and that she was possibly the murderer herself. Neither God nor human justice was present on Floreana.
 
 But the mailbox survived. There is no evolutionary explanation for it: no-one who takes home and mails a letter will have more offspring. 
 
 It is equally hard to say that Freud or Piaget participate in the success of the mailbox. The mailbox does not protect us against the unknown in the dark or the chaotic forces within ourselves. At most, one can say that it is a satisfying game, like marbles, where we rejoice in our cooperation; but, unlike marbles, it is a game played exactly once in the lives of most people who see it, and then it is almost certainly played with strangers. In fact, one will almost certainly never learn the identity of the person who mailed one's letter.
 
 The mailbox represents a Prisoner's Dilemma, where mailing each others' letters represents the maximum payoff for cooperation. But the mailbox should not work under the strict rules of the Prisoner's Dilemma, because there are no consequences for defection. Most tourists will never return to the mailbox, and defections are impossible to detect anyway; therefore, someone who leaves a letter but does not mail one will never be known and cannot be punished. But the mailbox continues anyway, decade after decade, and almost everyone who visits leaves a letter and mails one.
 
 The mailbox succeeds because it is a beautiful idea that appeals to everyone who learns about it. Everyone who visits wishes to participate in the success of the meme of the mailbox. It is the idea of the mailbox which causes the letters in it to be mailed.  From "Morality Without God"

Evolution, assuredly, has not stopped. However, the example you have used will not serve as an example of evolution.
 
 Humans are taller now because pregnant women are generally better nourished than they were a thousand years ago, because children are generally better nourished. Another factor in tallness may be consumption of cow's milk which contains growth hormones to stimulate calves to grow rapidly and to enlarge their skeletons rapidly.
 
 The status of women has improved in most nations of the world and where the status of women is high, they are given the food they need during pregnancy, as well as food for their children.
 
 Note that in patriarchal cultures such as Saudi Arabia, the women are quite tiny and people generally are shorter than they are in more advanced nations. Another factor in the tininess of women in Saudi Arabia is that they are forced into marriage at such very young ages and are pregnant before their bodies have matured.
